review_title: All my expectations and hopes were crashed
pros: Benefits like health insurance , are very good. Some of the policies like training,hiring are very employee friendly.Training opportunities are good.
cons:
IBM does not accommodate working mothers needs at all. Although it states so many things but at the end of day implementation of those policies are not met.
Like I am a working mom , I wanted a role based out of Dallas and I had clarified that at the time of hiring itself.After couple of months of my joining ,my manager informed me the project for which we hired you is now not with IBM then they start pushing you for taking outstation projects involving travel.
For a new comer to the company searching for project by themselves very tough and they will tell you that you have to network yourself and get to a project when most people are at client locations. How do you network? There is hardly any support from management or HR in project search.
Finally after a year they will let you know we will have to let go as there is no work
During my 1 year with IBM apart from 2 months on a project all i heard was work is in pipeline project is in pipeline. Some of the projects i later got to know are hiring in my local area and we were not given the chance to be part of the project

job_title: Process Engineer in Hopewell Junction, NY
pros: I feel the company is pretty good with the work life balance.  Because the company is very advance some are even allowed to work remotely.  As an engineer supporting the manufacturing line you could essentially do a good portion of your job from home.  The company also provides good benefits at least compared to the other companies I have looked at which is really only two other companies.  They also have other little perks like different corporate discounts and rewards for great achievements (eventhough I hear they are not as good as they used to be).  I did enjoy most of the people are work with.  There are a good number of helpful people with in the company
cons: It seems there is a lot of backwards thinking in IBM and not just within some divisions.  It seems to be company wide.  It seems like changes always loop back around someone.  The high level managers think they have an understanding of what happens at the lowest level but don't.  There always seems to be a different panic attack each day so it can get stressful at times.  Pick your day and you have some serious issue going on.  The meetings are endless and often pointless.  The meetings always make it seems like it's deja vu.  There is more time spent talking about the problem than actually going to correct it.

review_title: IBM must address the bloated management in its Global Services division
job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: IBM is in the cutting edge of rolling out technology solutions to meet business challenges.  Whatever IBM comes out with like eBusiness, Information on Demand, Websphere, etc. is copied by the competition, but IBM is always ahead of the game.  The level of technical competence is high in the right pockets, which ensures that they could always execute with the right people on the team as members or SMEs.
cons: There is an incredible amount of overhead between the people who do the work and the level of associate partners, partners, regional managers, practice leads, practice managers, industry leads, industry VPs, competency VP, etc in the Services area.  I would generate about $385,000-$555,000 every year in consulting revenue for the company, but my bonuses and raises were a joke for the kind of contribution I made to the company.  The overhead in Services must be addressed.

review_title: Smart people and good for resume, but not a great experience
pros: The people I work with are really smart. Great for the resume, as IBM is a pretty well respected company. My coworkers have left for great tech companies and top 5 business schools. Good benefits (but getting worse).
cons: Hard to get recognition for good work. You're only as good as your PBC rating (IBM's end of year rating system), which can get pretty political and bureaucratic. Management is out of touch with employees and how they feel about the company. People at my level are VERY negative about IBM. Lots of turnover. In Public Sector you can get stuck on a project forever (I've been on the same one for my entire time at IBM and would have to burn a lot of bridges to get off of it, if I even could). 401K matching once a year is bad for employees. Do not feel connected to company as a whole. Management is out of touch with how employees feel about the company. Hard to motivate for IBM's success when the company doesn't give bonuses or raises for people who are supposedly performing well. After almost two years here, and performing very well according to all of my evaluations, I am actually making LESS money than when I started when you consider inflation and the fact that company healthcare costs have gone up.

job_title: Applications Programming Specialist in Okemos, MI
pros:
IBM is so big that the Pros/Cons depend somewhat on what group you are working in.

Where I work all my coworkers were good, hardworking people willing to help out. There is a good work life balance, lots of vacation days, sick leave, and flexible hours. Medical, Dental, and Health insurance.
cons:
Management has very poor communication with its employees. My direct manager goes months without checking in on my to see how things are going. Emails from upper management are full of near meaningless business jargon such as "Creating a playbook to sharpen your digital edge".

The business model in my group requires employees to find projects on their own. IBM does provide a tool for finding projects but often times that tool call doesn't list all the projects or lists incorrect information about the project. Often times, projects are found through less formal methods such as word of mouth.

Pay is atrocious. Far below the industry average.

Email spam. Various people from around the company send you emails about projects and events that are not relevant to you at all. It got so bad I had to create a junk mail folder.

pros:
First of all I am only talking about the group that I work in. It used to be called the Market Intelligence group but is now renamed to Market Insights to better recognize the fact that we are generating insights about the market and not just information. I feel that the best reason to work for my group in IBM is the flexibility of being able to work from home.  My teammates are located all over the US and in fact, all over the world.  We are measured by what we produce and not by our physical presence.  While sometimes there is no substitute for face to face contacts, by and large we are able to accomplish what we need through email, instant msging and phone calls. 

Another good reason is the many job opportunities in IBM - I can change jobs and not have to change companies. This means I can keep learning new skills without having to renegotiate a new corporate culture.
cons: It is a HUGE company and it is easy to lose sight of what it is you are trying to accomplish in your projects. IBM jobs in the US are pretty specialized so you often have to talk to many people in order to get something done. This can be very frustrating but I suppose this is the same for most large corporations. Pay increments are very small, compared to what I've heard about our competitors, I think our increments are pathetic. While the ability to work from home is a plus for me, it is also easy to become isolated. If one is new to the company, that can be very hard.

review_title: I would probably choose not to join IBM...
pros:
- The company's image, still...  At least for the general public, 'I work for IBM' means something...
- IBM is really serious about training, and very well organized for that.
cons:
- Way too much time spent dealing with processes...
- No chance to grow a team (at least in Software development): no organic growth, no new projects...
- Every year, only around half of the employees get a salary raise.  You may never get a raise if you're not (considered) better than your closest colleagues.  Say 'Bye!' to team spirit...
- Cost control is way too tight.  Some employees even start to buy computers on their own money to be able to do their job correctly! And travel is extremely restricted.

review_title: Looks great on the resume, but...
pros: You'd be working for a strong brand name that everyone recognises and respects. It's a global company that's interconnected, so there's many opportunities to work with people in other countries, and even pursue careers over there (if you play your cards right). There's the option to work from home, although that can sometimes pose a problem (see 'cons'). There's jobs for anyone of any background (Project Management, Sales, Accounting, Consulting, etc), but not everyone.
cons: Unless you're in the project management space, there's no formal training/hand-over proccess in most areas I've worked, so you'd be at the mercy of existing team members if you're new. Hands-on training can be poor. It's also difficult to achieve a strong team environment with synergy, because often people choose to work from home, and you don't get to speak with them face-to-face. Sometimes it's like you have to formally book a meeting just to see a member of your own team. Managers are good at what they do (technically), but lack important people skills - They're often task-orientated, and when under pressure, they focus solely their own survival than on their workers well-being. To be blunt, most managers I've experienced see their subordinates as tools rather than actual people.

review_title: Watson is a Great Organization Weighed Down by the Rest of IBM
job_title: Software Engineering Intern in Austin, TX
pros:
- Watson has an excellent design team and I appreciate the recent focus on design.
- My teammates are motivated, have a good work-life balance, and are fun to be around.
- They tried very hard to make the intern program fun and to bring us together socially. There were intern presentations, Main Event night, boat on Lake Austin.
- Pay was very good.
cons:
- Required to use internal dev tools like BlueMix that lower our productivity because they always crash.
- As an intern I came to the office every day but most workers at IBM "work from home" very often. I've heard that it's even worse outside of Watson.
- Pay arrived late, especially the promised Lump Sum Travel Reimbursement, which arrived 2 months after I had arrived.
- Senior management seems disconnected from reality on the ground. For example, there was a two-day intern finale event. They decided that the interns would spend paid work hours bagging rice for charity (which I think could be a great idea). They set a goal for 10,000 rice packets and we didn't pack that many during the scheduled events. The organizers were supposed to help with the whole process, but they didn't seem to care once the Instagram pictures were taken. So the rep from the charity was basically abandoned to pack the last 1,000 and pack it onto a truck.
- Lots of "not my problem" attitude about cleaning up common areas, sharing training data, etc. Most people are just concerned with their individual team.

review_title: IBM hates doing software development in the US
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Durham, NC
pros: IBM is still a great name to have on your resume. They do some pretty cool projects, and you learn to work hard at IBM. For some people, things turn out really well at IBM if they get the right first project.
cons: Projects are chronically understaffed. It's hard to get a good assignment. It seems the best work is hand-picked for certain people. YMMV, but the company is not interested in developing you. They will keep you in the same assignment for a long time, and make it very hard to transfer. In my case, I did a stint as a Support person. I then applied to a Development proper position (which I had done previously). I started out doing Development, but in less than 2 months, Support duties were added to my job, and then my job became that almost 100%. After years at that job working hard, I transferred to a new job, and I noticed that once again, I wasn't allowed to go to a Development proper position, they wanted me to do same job again!!!  Even though there was plenty of Development work to do on my new team, they would rather keep the project understaffed and behind schedule, than to hire one more ready and willing developer to help out, and go out of their way to keep me in a position I no longer wanted to perform.

review_title: Good Place to Start and Learn but not a Great Place to Stay Long-Term
job_title: Business Strategy/Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good place to get your start and learn about technology.   You will get to understand the dynamics of different business models(i.e. SaaS/PaaS/Hardware/On-Prem Software) and learn about new technologies (i.e. blockchain, AI, Quantum).   Option to work from home which lets you avoid the commute.
cons: Compensation is below market; my base pay was comparable to average pay according to Glassdoor but the bonus was basically non-existent.  I literally got ~$700 after tax for the bonus!   Many underfunded products/projects and long lead times to get things done lead to subpar products that aren't competitive.  No ability to retain good talent; see good people who can leave defect to other tech companies (i.e. Google, Microsoft, Salesforce, Startups, etc.) all the time.  Lack of opportunity to grow in the company.  Since IBM is shrinking, there are almost no attractive opportunities to switch roles and get promoted.   IBM is getting it's butt kicked by Google, Amazon, and Microsoft in IaaS/SaaS/PaaS and AI and it is unlikely IBM will be able to reverse this market trend anytime soon.  Senior Management is too secure in their positions.  IBM has underperformed vs. peers for a decade yet most of the Senior Management team have retained their positions.

review_title: Be very leery of IBM as an employer.
job_title: Senior Consulting IT Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Looks good on your resume when you find an employer that wants to keep you long term.     Positions in IBM customer facing roles build skills that will greatly benefit you in your next job, and you may learn how to recognize employers that you do not want to consider in the future.  IBM still has excellent products and these are worthwhile assets in your kit for future employment, especially if you are technical, and for pre-sales technical roles they still provide time to get and keep those technical skills.   You still get to work with some of the finest people in the IT industry, though they do not tend tend to stay long any more once they understand the way IBM views them and their compensation.
cons: Lower pay than other companies, benefits in a death spiral and management lack of respect for the employee.   Compensation growth is non-existent, in fact likely to be negative regardless of your performance.  If you are not in a customer facing role your job is most probably going to a low cost country, though it may not happen quickly (IBM is accomplishing this slowly so it does not attract too much media attention).   A mobile workforce, as IBM has, often means working alone without support, and without adequate tools.   IBM expense and infrastructure policies mean spending hours a week accounting for travel and activity, which if you have service level agreements must be done on your own time.

review_title: Great company to work for, but has become managers company
pros:
1. Encourages innovation.
2. Probably one of the very few companies to provide Sick Leave on humanitarian grounds
3. Good work life balance
4. Flexibility to work from home and is not restricted to certain positions unlike in many companies
5. Effective utilization of resources
cons:
1. Work in compensation, probably all you can get is what you can bargain the first time
2. Manager driven company where employee has no say
3. HR in IBM India isn't effective at all, sharing an issue with HR is directed to the manager which is ridiculous.
4. Managers keep you on your toes without even knowing what they want and what they are looking for at the end.

pros:
Great people work in there. 
The experience is in overall positive, but it is the kind of job that you cannot do for too long.
You have freedom to move to other teams in the country in case you hate your job. They also promote the rotation to try to avoid that people get to confortable on their job.
cons:
It varies on every country IBM is in, but in Slovakia you get no overtime paid, in any way. That means that you will stay very late sometimes to support deals you are getting no comission for, for basically no extra money or vacation. You can cope on that for few weeks, but not for long.

It is extremely inflexible in many ways. You can start from the bottom, perform perfectly and get a better position, but your salary will not be raised in a year for a battery of reasons: Frozen budget, the raises take place only twice a year, your salary cannot be uplifted more than 20% a year... They recognize the hard work, but they are extremely reluctant to pay for it.

They have stupid internal policies. Everybody knows they are stupid but nobody stands up and shouts for a change.

For an IT company, the technological resources are not the best. They try to sell cloud but don´t offer it to the teams, the file size of an employee is 150mb when your gmal account has gigas...

job_title: IT Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Working remotely, health benefits, coworkers, and first line manager.
cons:
401(k) matching once a year, the lack of being able to reach anyone human in HR or any other department, lack of communication from the top. 
The biggest drawback, the constant layoff's, or as IBM calls them, Resource Actions.  While Companies layoff employee's, it is usually to rid themselves of deadwood.  At IBM, the cut to make the balance sheet look better.  Currently they are laying off as the Company transforms itself, but after 4 years of declining revenues, quarterly layoffs, the problem is not the workers, it is the upper management.  Being in sales if I have a few bad quarters, I get terminated, upper management has them and they get a bonus?  
Don't apply here if you want an employer you can grow with, here you will go down with the ship that is sinking faster than the Titanic. 
The CEO keeps changing direction and shedding assets to keep the shareholders earning.
The ship is sinking a slow but deliberate death, unless the top managers are changed it will continue to decline.

review_title: Good part is only the Brand name
pros:
1> Brand Name
2> Only Fixed Salary but no Variable Pay in your CTC. 
3> Less work pressure like Govt Sector ( good for those who wants less pressure)
cons:
There is a myth at IBM " Nothing is Free".... Its not a myth instead this is truth.
One simple example : There is no Coffee Machine in the Breakout area.

1> Manager oriented company there is no existence of HR. If you raise any HR query you will get a mailer saying to reach out to your Manager and the next mail comes from them is about the feedback.
2> Though IBM is renound for its WFH facility but Managers are trying to bring it down to show credit to their senior manager.
3> Once you get into IBM, on the portal you will see some extra amount (0-1.5 lakh) as performance/GDP, something bonus related, but you will be end up getting peanuts only.  
4> Medical insurance is only 3L but you can't include your parents in it. for the basic insurance policy of yourself also you need to pay some Premium from your pocket ( remember that myth "nothing is free").
5> Less work pressure like Govt Sector ( bad for those who wants good exposure)
6> There is no guarantee on proper allocation to project.  moreover there may be huge discrepancies in terms of designation that you get in your offer letter and the actual role you are going to play.
7> No transport facility for the employee.
8> Manager oriented company.

review_title: IBM is an average place to work -- negotiate a high starting salary, as it will be with you for a while.
job_title: Advisory Hardware Engineer in East Fishkill, NY
pros: Cutting edge technology (CMOS H/W), very talented engineers, great and grand projects.  There are some really smart people here; in the development teams, and in research.  It's great to have a research team to help tackle really difficult problems.  Also, generous vacation (though you can't always take it and you can't accumulate it), flexible work-at-home deals depending on your area.  Decent initial salary.
cons: Compensation is poor. Once you're in, raises are non-existent or really small.  Same for bonuses.  And that's for exemplary performers.  Promotions are very rare, particularly for the technical team.  Management is odd: 1st/2nd line managers spend most of their time trying to be "Project Managers", not too much focus actual management.  There's a project management hierarchy that overlaps with these first lines, and adds little value ( though that might be the best career path).  Zero training. Zero travel. Development projects are overbooked. IBM is really pushing off-shoring to India.  You have to do your job, plus train a team of Indian developers; Middle management is pretty bad, they aim to please Sr management, customers, without consideration to their team.  Sr Management reaps millions, off-shores, and lays technical people off ; their is not a good connection between the team and Sr Management.  7-10 levels of managers in between, too much.

review_title: IBM doesn't care about your personal growth, just matches you with positions to fulfill needs.  Jobs are going off-shore
job_title: Managing Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros:
Pro's - 
Working from home flexibility
Benefits
Starting salary is on-par
Peers -  alot of smart ppl and workaholics
Looks good on resume
cons:
Con's - 
-  I was asked to move to save on expenses (yea right I would sell my house in this economy, so they backed off)
-  No Tuition Reimbursement  (IBM does not support you in getting your MBA)
-  No career growth
-  Your Blue Pages Manager doesn't really care about you.  No communication,  just wants to be sure you are staffed.  Not really a mentor.
-  Alot of the best and brightest ppl are leaving IBM as the economy turns
-  Raise - what are they?   Solid performance reviews,  what a joke.  
-  Layoffs -  laid off abotu 15% of their staff last year to create jobs in India.  
-  Perks taken away - No more Thank you awards to save costs
-  Morale is low
-  Work hours -  can be long and have to give up weekends.  It's up to you to say no.

pros: The people are the best thing about IBM. There are so many bright, ambitious people. The peoples arise when managers stifle the employee creativity. There are many opportunities, to move around within the company but the way to apply for internal postings automatically sends an email to your boss. Once they know you are looking things can go south. The technologies they are exploring are interesting but it is limited to certain teams.
cons:
The amount of red tape that is in the way of doing anything new or outside of the box is crazy. The senior management is old but they want to pretend they are new and cutting edge. The leadership leaves lots to be desired. 

The amount of paper pushing stifles creativity. We get hundreds of emails daily. It is overwhelming. Plus there is very little follow-through. They want teams to keep presenting new and exciting ideas but very little comes to fruition. It can be a very frustrating work environment. 

The ranking system has been a problem for many years. Employees are ranked against each other, which fosters competition, which kills collaboration. 

The rounds and rounds of layoffs is demoralizing.  Layoffs happen all the time and team dynamics are decimated. If they want true evaluation of people then they should create a 360 review process where everyone is judged on their behavior by all those they work with. The cream will rise to the top this way.

pros:
WAS a very good  place for people who aspire to pursue a technology career. But mid management politics has ruined over time.

IBMers who  are  with the company with more that 10 years - can be looked upto. They are some of t he best minds at work in the industry. Luck if you get to work with them.

Support for personal work life balance -. Great 

Working from home -for all employees. -Great
cons:
Middle management has taken to politics big time - and its become a  sad state of affairs.
I hope IBM goes back to its glory days under Ginni and specifically in India. But the overall mindset of middle level managers is really depressing.
Have been with IBM for more than 6 years. and its sad to see how deteriorated  it has become. 

I have tried  to analyze this as rationally as I could - and trust me- the quality has gone from  being good  to just average.

Your peers would prefer gossiping more than talking about work at hand. Moreover, I have seen this prevalent across the IBM geography .  Have traveled quite a lot - and this is really prevalent.

Lastly, when taking interviews the set *quality* criteria have been reduced by 70% to increase strength -reducing the overall quality of peer group

These guys (mid level managers) have gone to threatening people if  they decide to go against certain policies. There is NO fear among them. Sad  state of things

review_title: IBM India is unclear, non transparent and lead by incompetent people who value flattery more than talent
pros:
Brand name to get associated with.
Flexible working hours which after a long time work against employee. 
Option of working remotely.
cons:
This may not hold true for entire lot working out there. It is based no my experience with bunch of people working @ NCR region. 

This place is full of non competent, unfair managers who lack professionalism in big way. 
No feedbacks are given on performance of employees, general thumb of rule is the more you flatter , more benefits you earn. 
There is no such thing as Human Resources department, or employee grievances cell, people managers have all the powers and they make wrong use of same. 
There is no clarity, nothing is transparent, different rules apply for different people. 
Employee with commendable technical ability and proven excellent performances may be declared lowest contributor by tagging silly reasons like phone number is missing in signature of your mail.
My advise is do not look up to anyone for help while having issues with your seniors, if you do, your name will be openly declared to entire world and then you will have to face consequences.   
And in case you are looking for role models this not the right place, you for sure will never like to be one of those around.

review_title: Used to be my best dream job
pros:
If you love exceptionally great technology you may get the change to work with it if you work in IBM.
Great technological legacy: just take the mainframe over 48 years old and still going strong
Continuous investment in technological innovation
Nurturer of Unix in general AIX and Linux
Great CPU tech: Power and System p or Power 7 in new Power System
Great storage tech: DS8000 Series
cons: 5 years ago I would have give it 10 stars out of 5... my enthusiasm has been squashed since then by the cohort of so called "freezes": education freeze, Q4 spending freeze, travel freeze, beginning of Q1 freeze, end of Q2 freeze etc.

review_title: Need to focus and move fast
pros: A very large company with many career potentials. Worldwide presence makes it a great company to work for if you have an interest to work overseas. IBM was ahead of its time in so many ways including embracing social, open source, and cloud as the core of its business. Company has very smart people working in it. Work/life balance is good.
cons:
As much as the company was ahead of its time in many areas: cloud, social, mobile, and open source, it didn't do enough to make a lasting impact in the industry. There are smart, strategic IBMers who had long identified those up-trends. But senior management hung on to status-quo, focusing on mainframes, middle-ware, and once high margin hardware business. 

There is little to no career development. Most people are "tenured" are staying to retire. Executives are compensated based on earnings per share. This inherently steer them to cost cut in places where it matters most: high quality hires, education, and technology investment. Short-term gains and complacency lead to long-term decline of the company. Most executives are just waiting for retirement, leaving a shadow of a company that IBM once was.

job_title: Summit Program Solution Sales Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Summit is life changing! Throughout the 6-9 months of training, people are taken from being recent graduates with little experience to young sales professionals ready to sell for Big Blue. In the program, you learn how to not only be an effective sales person, but you also learn about how to engage with C-level execs. The salary is outstanding and the company is focused on investing in you through education. Managers are fantastic and truly care about enabling you to succeed. There is some travel involved. Lastly, the best part about Summit is that you are put with 30-40 people your age that you stay with throughout the program. This is not only great for networking, but it's absolutely crucial to building the culture and your experience at IBM. Some of the people in my group have become my best friends.
cons: There are some cons about working here- IBM is an extremely large company and it's easy to get lost in the mix. It was also difficult initially to find enough work to do because they start everyone off slow. However, with that being said, it's on YOU to make sure you have your needs met. Whether that is by asking for more work, getting involved on different project teams, or telling your manager you're overwhelmed. A lot of my peers complain about things in the program that they have complete control over to change.

review_title: Be the change you want to see in the world… become an IBMer
job_title: Digital Sales Stream Channel Manager in Coppell, TX
pros:
If you want to be successful and change the world you work for a company like IBM.  IBM is on the cutting edge of technology and the opportunities are endless to those willing to work for it and earn it.  Make no mistake about it… its highly competitive, edgy, stressful and at times it can feel like pure madness.  This is what it takes to be a world leader in technology.  IBM can help you tap into the greatest version of you and come out on the other side a contributor to the brilliance that is IBM.
If you are interested in more than just benefits and you want to make a difference in today’s world… IBM is the place for you.  (FYI… benefits are great).  If you are just looking for a paycheck, “swipe LEFT”.  All things being equal IBM has their share of issues just like every other company.  No matter what company you work for, when faced with a challenge, you can complain about it or build a business case to fix it.  At IBM you can be part of the solution that fixes the problem.  
IBM is a wealth of vision and inspiration and always looking forward to the future.  I would challenge anyone reading this to be the change you want to see in the world… become an IBMer.

One piece of advice… It’s called BIG BLUE for a reason… do not get lost in the ocean…NETWORK.
cons: I prefer to call them challenges... all companies have them.  Nothing major you can't overcome.

review_title: Don’t let the big name fool you.
pros: New technology if you can find a way to get involved with it.
cons:
No motivators other than “be lucky to have a job”. 
No yearly pay increase. Once you’re hired in, getting a raise is next to impossible even for stellar work. You get great reviews but keep the same salary, year after year, so you’re in essence working for less money due to inflation and when cost of living goes up each year. I’ve been working for ibm for 10 years, hired in at 100k, gotten great reviews for doing more, growing my skill set, advancing IBMs client base and technical position, and in the 10 years, I’ve gotten a couple 1200$ profit sharing bonus and a 1% pay increase and one 2% pay increase.......in 10 years. So I’m in essence making about 17% less less than when I started. (My money doesn’t go as far as it did 10 years ago, doesn’t pay the same amount of bills). And manage always says “maybe next year” year after year, until burnout sets in, our careers have been damaged from the emotional and mental torture that working for a company like this does to you.

review_title: Lots of opportunities, and lots of management.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: The company is involved in many products and businesses, so there is a lot of opportunity for doing different things throughout your career.  People tend to stay with the same job for two to five years before moving on to do something different, and this is supported fully by management.  There are even opportunities for moving to different areas within the United States, or even to other countries, if you are interested in seeing new places, both on temporary or permanent assignments.  If you wish, you can have a varied career, changing jobs as your interests change, while maintaining the continuity and benefits of having a single employer.
cons: The company can be somewhat management-heavy at times.  Sometimes it appears that there are levels of middle management that exist simply to keep people busy.  This seems to be especially the case in some of the older organizations that have been producing the same or similar products for many years.  This tends to create a lot of politics, especially when dealing with people in different management chains who seem to be getting a completely different vision for the direction of the project.  Good first-line managers shield their employees from this, while bad ones can make it nearly impossible to be productive.

review_title: Great perks for sales reps, almost makes up for the internal BS you have to deal with
job_title: Sales Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Perks as a sales rep, laptop, expensive dinners with customers, rental cars, flights, hotels, box seats to sporting events with customers, phone and internet bill all expensable with corporate card.  Working from home is great too, you could work from Jamaica, and no one would know.  The IBM brand name is great too, you will never be denied a meeting because you represent IBM.  The conferences are top notch and are done at the best hotels, celebrity keynote speakers, and if you have customers, you get to spoil them and yourself all week long with expensive dinners even bottle service at the best clubs in Vegas (if your manager approves).
cons:
Huge quotas, internal politics, red tape, conference calls, constant fear of layoffs, backstabbing when things go wrong, the amount of internal administrative crap you have to do that takes away from your productivity, cadence calls, etc.

If you have a crappy manager, your life will suck at IBM as a sales rep...period.

Getting taken off of accounts in the middle of the year, or at the beginning of the year is frustrating as a sales rep b/c this is supposed to be a relationship business.  When you're best friends with a CIO, and you have millions of dollars coming your way for years spread out over 4 quarters, it's hard to see that account go to someone else due to restructuring.

review_title: Excellent environment, excellent team of people, great opportunities if you're in the right place at the right time.
pros: Relaxed work environment, access to a worldwide network of people with amazing experiences, IBM has pretty much done everything in the IT industry there is to be done and all of this has added to the plethora of knowledge contained within its knowledge network. If you're part of the consulting team you get the opportunity to work on excellent client facing projects and if you're in the right place at the right time you can pretty much define your own career. There are several career IBMers in senior positions and it is a privilege to work with them and learn. Work life balance is generally encouraged and work from home is a real and valid option and not just marketing, giving you the ability to balance your professional and personal commitments.
cons:
Its a large organisation with "processes" that have evolved over a 100 years and as such has led to a "red tape" like feel. This also causes the organisation to feel a little archaic and slow. Several of the policies in consulting that impact travelling for work are not very employee friendly. Significant variations in salaries at same level as you can negotiate a high salary when you join and the longer you spend the lower you slip below the market average. 

From a consulting viewpoint, the focus is on increasingly using the consulting workforce to leverage IBM software for work which is in my opinion counterproductive as it consulting is best when it is solution agnostic and aligned to figuring out what suits the client best rather than having to retrofit the IBM solutions into the client requirements.

job_title: Global Technology Services Sales Specialist in London, England
pros:
Best of IBM 2017! I have just come back from a 'money can't buy' trip to Hawaii. A nomination only event awarded to the highest achieving IBMers of 2016 (and their partners) who have contributed to making IBM the world’s premiere cognitive solutions and cloud platform company. 
This event showcased everything that is good about IBM. I have mixed with IBMers from all over the world, hearing about what they did to earn their place on Best of IBM. I have been inspired by IBM's leaders in Services (GTS), Watson and Cloud. I have heard guest speakers who have shared their stories of perseverance, hard work and achievement and I have enjoyed the talents of numerous bands, singers (Jennifer Hudson!!!) and musicians all brought in to entertain us. I also have to mention the unusual chocolates inspired by Chef Watson delivered to our rooms one night.

All of this in the beautiful backdrop of Hawaii. We were treated to some wonderful traditional dancing, chanting and fire-throwing to depict the story of goddess Pele. I have toured the volcanoes and seen active lava flow, I have dived to a depth of 100ft aboard the 'Atlantis' submarine and I have eaten the most delicious food for the entirety of the trip.
Hard work really does get recognised IBM and recognition doesn't get any better than Best of IBM!
cons: There is a lot of pressure at IBM to deliver sales on a week by week basis and sometimes the longer game can be lost in our desperation to bring in deals within a particular quarter. This can create interesting behaviour within the management and can impact morale among the troops.

pros:
We were allowed to work remotely but it ended right after the layoffs.
Pay was above average.  
Some really good people worked there.
cons:
Layoffs.  First month I was there, they laid off 10% of my department, layoffs continued all year long.   

Constant focus changes from C levels. CEO and her managers are to blame for this company failing month after month.  22 months of decline, its obvious its the upper management that needs to be "laid off".

Management were told to do mandatory PIP ( Performance Improvement Plans ) on N number of people.  I saw the email. It is highly unethical.

They accidentally posted their plan on slack saying they outsourcing our jobs overseas, then they said "oh we not.." yet few months later.. they did. They Lie directly to the employees.

The new C level came to the office once, talked for a full hour on "How her son is doing, and how he is the best son ever."  Then 5 minutes of sales need to increase by 400%, then tells no one what the plan is.  After the 5 minutes, she went back talking about her son.  I wish I was joking on this.  This is not leadership, it is a friends of friends network.

review_title: Good in terms of job stability but bad when it comes to pay employees who are working for the company for long time.
pros: If you are looking for job stability then definitely it is a company which you should look for. Even you do not perform well managment will try their best to fit you somewhere.
cons:
They hire guys with atleast 2-3 years of experience in BPO's as Lead Operations (Band 5) and pay them twice or thrice for the same work which they pay to Band- 3 or 4, who is already working in the company for 3 or 4 years. 

Facilities are pathetic. Many times coffee or tea is not available in coffee machine and tissue paper and soap in washroom and cafetaria. Especially on weekends.

If you are stuck on a call and miss your cab you are not going to get another cab. You have to pester Transport Supervisors for alignment and you will get a drop at your pickup/drop point. On weekends if you are the only person who is suppossed to get pickup or drop then, transport is not going to send cab for you and will make unimaginable pretensions. 
They stopped providing cabs in the day time. Employees who do grave yard shift go on their own in afternoon, imagine this situation during summers when you are occupied by sleep and going home on your own.
Managers who made this policy should do graveyard shift during summers then go by public transport. Then they will have a better understanding of the situation. 
There is no place where you can escalate any issue with transport.

review_title: Great place to work but projects only as good as what MDs win
pros:
Mostly friendly environment 
Perks - staying away from home, hotels, travel, generous AMEX budget etc 
Range of opportunities to excel 
360 review of performance from colleagues, managers and clients - fair system 
Loads of ways to get involved in 'giveback' or CSR activities - they genuinely care
Supportive environment for women 
Flexible working - most of times at least one day per week working from home 
Accessibility - most senior consultants, partners etc are down to earth and approachable IBMers don't take themselves too seriously 
TRAINING - I had a ridiculous amount of training opportunities both at the start and throughout, quite a few are online and will need to be done in your own time but excellent training nevertheless 
Work life balance is generally quite good if you factor in that on a number of projects you will need to work away from home for SIGNIFICANT amounts of time 
Benefits good... but**
cons:
Lack of interesting / varied projects at times - unfortunately this depends on loads of other factors outside of company's control 
Pay is lower - compared to other big IT consultancies - this should really be resolved considering clients are charged so much and IBM is at the more 'expensive end' of the market 
Lack of sexiness - so that down-to-earth feel can manifest itself in terms of people's dress and things like that - IBMers are not the stoosh and sexy McKinsey types - but maybe that's a good thing 
Lack of COMPANY STATIONERY... like wtf?
Working away from home - this does encroach on life after sometime
**but compensation, generally quite poor, at least starting out as a graduate

review_title: Outsourced from Pepsi & it's been downhill ever since
pros: IBM is a good name to put on your resume. Nearly unlimited sick days and good vacation/floating holiday package. Flex scheduling. Ability to work from home part time as long as your accounts are maintained.
cons: High turnover, little to no employee appreciation, bad pay, people who were with Pepsi for years are now racing to get out the door, have trouble replacing people as fast as they're leaving so that puts more workload on the employees that are left and even though you may have 1 person doing 2 peoples' job, getting overtime is like pulling teeth, mediocre training for new hires (who are all temps, they never hire on with IBM), lack of communication around the office (people who have been with Pepsi and IBM since the beginning are leaving and leadership doesn't even communicate this to the teams, its all hush hush like people disappear into thin air), this list could go on and on

pros:
- The experience you gain is for life. IBM shaped me as a professional, and I will be forever thankful for the experience,
- Training courses, mentorship programs, drop-ins are incredible.
- Thousands of opportunities to change areas and learn new things.
cons:
- The salary is very lower than the Market average.
- The workload is too high, the staff is always shorter than it should. Overtimes are not exceptional, but a routine reality.
- The stress level is constantly high, many employees and managers are under anxiety medication to handle it.
- There are too many career bureaucracies distracting the professional from the real delivery and real company's needs.
- The technical career is limited, and it results in too many technical managers with no people skill, and no interest to develop it.
- The American Way of managing can be really cruel and inhumane. People are sad and frustrated in this company.
- Quality as Service is unpriorityzed. IBM has gone to a path of cutting the costs and budget that lead to a very poor quality staff and service, and the results are shown in the company's results in the last years.

review_title: Standard Expectations for a Big Company
pros:
- Great coworkers
- Good managers
- Ability to work on multiple technologies
- Relatively decent work/life balance
- Great 401k match

Life at IBM certainly isn't boring. You will spend a lot of time listening to long timers about the good old days of when they rewarded people and had fringe benefits. Just ignore them. It's about enjoying your team and the projects you are working on. People at the company are overall great and there is a lot of keen enthusiasm. Fewer diva programmers than most places and a lot of knowledge to acquire if you pay your dues. There are so many technologies to dip into and if you hit up someone from another business unit and offer to help they are more than happy to offload some tasks for you to learn with. People just enjoy sharing here and it's more difficult to not let yourself spread too much.
cons:
- Low moral due to resource actions 
- Lingering stacked rating system issues
- Almost no appealing benefits

IBM is a big company and has the same problem of any big company. I'd caution to give only as much time as you feel good about because bonuses are rare, acknowledgement is thin, and overall promotions and advancement are up to a roulette of factors. Basically those extra hours you put in are for your own self satisfaction because IBM can't reward top behavior of anyone but sellers right now.

review_title: IBM is a great technology company - job satisfaction depends on job role, environment & YOURSELF
pros:
+ great technology
+ some amazingly good technical  and sales professionals
+ interesting challenges
+ worldwide accounts 
+ huge industry range
+ global company
cons:
I cannot speak for all of IBM. This accounts for my personal experience at IBM Dublin (Ballycoolin):

- too hierarchical, i.e. too many layers of management
- too metrics driven
- lack of incentives for people to want to perform 
- too reactive = lack of proactive employee- and business-centric management
- people are assigned job roles that are not in line with their qualifications, skill and personal career targets leading to increased fluctuation

job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Chicago, IL
pros: Wide variety of industries, many high-quality people to work with on projects, reputation opens doors to interesting engagements, competitive wages. Hiring process was fairly well run.
cons:
For such a well-established technology company, searching their practitioner database for reference work and relevant IP yields documents that are often over five years old in a foreign language.

Very inefficient staffing, ad hoc training and career planning...

I was hired as an experienced professional, given a laptop with basic administrative training and then left to fend for myself with no initial projects in mind when I was hired in so as to help establish my network. It took several months to become staffed on the first project.

Variable compensation is only given to a very small percentage at the very top of a year's given achievers and only when the company is performing well so don't count on more than your base salary.

review_title: Change on the horizon, or is it?
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: If your job allows, the ability to be able to work from home is a definite plus because I am able to avoid Austin's commutes.  The benefit package is pretty  good if you are single.
cons: The thinking behind and implementation of the ineffective and destructive performance review process is supposed to be changing this year.  The challenge for the management team will be how to effectively change the thinking behind the old approach to performance review, with it's focus on "distributions" or quotas. This thinking is very ingrained in our corporate culture. Sadly, the previous system was build on outright untruths formally perpetuated by the management team, such as, "There is no quota system.", which is legendary within IBM. You cannot build a team when staff are effectively played off against each other to improve their "relative contribution".  This would be at the heart of why staff avoid taking on projects with inherent risk because they are afraid of being punished if they don't achieve an aggressive goal by loosing their meager pay increase, being ranked lower, and possibly becoming the target of a layoff.

job_title: Senior Managing Consultant in Southfield, MI
pros: Global reach, a lot of bright people, brand recognition (though it is skewed towards computing even today). Base pay was good.
cons:
Be careful, experienced professionals! I was dropped in at a relatively high level and had not projects from the get-go in the 4th quarter, and they were not closing a lot of work at that time. I didn't get on a billable project for almost six months. In month 17, I was given a lay-off notice based on my prior year performance because of that 1st quarter with no billable utilization... Also, be wary of Partner and Associate Partner underlying interests - watch you back.

I thought I'd have a great opportunity to help out on large projects and run small projects - with all the breadth of industry and the thousands of "open seats", but without that early opportunity to really get known, you are dead. I had some significant successes in industry before moving to this role, but the capabilities were not easily conveyed given this lack of early opportunity to work on things in front of key decision-makers.
